trans-unit.source: description="Data in your Microsoft Azure storage account is replicated for durability and high availability.
trans-unit.target: description="Data in your Microsoft Azure storage account is replicated for durability and high availability.

trans-unit.source: Replication options include locally redundant storage (LRS), zone-redundant storage (ZRS), geo-redundant storage (GRS), and read-access geo-redundant storage (RA-GRS)."
trans-unit.target: Replication options include locally redundant storage (LRS), zone-redundant storage (ZRS), geo-redundant storage (GRS), and read-access geo-redundant storage (RA-GRS)."

trans-unit.source: The data in your Microsoft Azure storage account is always replicated to ensure durability and high availability, meeting the <link><linkText>Azure Storage SLA</linkText><title></title></link> even in the face of transient hardware failures.
trans-unit.target: The data in your Microsoft Azure storage account is always replicated to ensure durability and high availability, meeting the <link><linkText>Azure Storage SLA</linkText><title></title></link> even in the face of transient hardware failures.

trans-unit.source: When you create a storage account, you must select one of the following replication options:
trans-unit.target: When you create a storage account, you must select one of the following replication options:

trans-unit.source: The following table provides a quick overview of the differences between LRS, ZRS, GRS, and RA-GRS, while subsequent sections address each type of replication in more detail.
trans-unit.target: The following table provides a quick overview of the differences between LRS, ZRS, GRS, and RA-GRS, while subsequent sections address each type of replication in more detail.

trans-unit.source: Data is replicated across multiple facilities.
trans-unit.target: Data is replicated across multiple facilities.

trans-unit.source: Data can be read from the secondary location as well as from the primary location.
trans-unit.target: Data can be read from the secondary location as well as from the primary location.

trans-unit.source: Number of copies of data maintained on separate nodes.
trans-unit.target: Number of copies of data maintained on separate nodes.

trans-unit.source: Locally redundant storage (LRS) replicates your data within the region in which you created your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Locally redundant storage (LRS) replicates your data within the region in which you created your storage account.

trans-unit.source: To maximize durability, every request made against data in your storage account is replicated three times.
trans-unit.target: To maximize durability, every request made against data in your storage account is replicated three times.

trans-unit.source: These three replicas each reside in separate fault domains and upgrade domains.
trans-unit.target: These three replicas each reside in separate fault domains and upgrade domains.

trans-unit.source: A fault domain (FD) is a group of nodes that represent a physical unit of failure and can be considered as nodes belonging to the same physical rack.
trans-unit.target: A fault domain (FD) is a group of nodes that represent a physical unit of failure and can be considered as nodes belonging to the same physical rack.

trans-unit.source: An upgrade domain (UD) is a group of nodes that are upgraded together during the process of a service upgrade (rollout).
trans-unit.target: An upgrade domain (UD) is a group of nodes that are upgraded together during the process of a service upgrade (rollout).

trans-unit.source: The three replicas are spread across UDs and FDs to ensure that data is available even if hardware failure impacts a single rack and when nodes are upgraded during a rollout.
trans-unit.target: The three replicas are spread across UDs and FDs to ensure that data is available even if hardware failure impacts a single rack and when nodes are upgraded during a rollout.

trans-unit.source: A request returns successfully only once it has been written to all three replicas.
trans-unit.target: A request returns successfully only once it has been written to all three replicas.

trans-unit.source: While geo-redundant storage (GRS) is recommended for most applications, locally redundant storage may be desirable in certain scenarios:
trans-unit.target: While geo-redundant storage (GRS) is recommended for most applications, locally redundant storage may be desirable in certain scenarios:

trans-unit.source: LRS is less expensive than GRS, and also offers higher throughput.
trans-unit.target: LRS is less expensive than GRS, and also offers higher throughput.

trans-unit.source: If your application stores data that can be easily reconstructed, you may opt for LRS.
trans-unit.target: If your application stores data that can be easily reconstructed, you may opt for LRS.

trans-unit.source: Some applications are restricted to replicating data only within a single region due to data governance requirements.
trans-unit.target: Some applications are restricted to replicating data only within a single region due to data governance requirements.

trans-unit.source: If your application has its own geo-replication strategy, then it may not require GRS.
trans-unit.target: If your application has its own geo-replication strategy, then it may not require GRS.

trans-unit.source: Zone-redundant storage (ZRS) replicates your data across two to three facilities, either within a single region or across two regions, providing higher durability than LRS.
trans-unit.target: Zone-redundant storage (ZRS) replicates your data across two to three facilities, either within a single region or across two regions, providing higher durability than LRS.

trans-unit.source: If your storage account has ZRS enabled, then your data is durable even in the case of failure at one of the facilities.
trans-unit.target: If your storage account has ZRS enabled, then your data is durable even in the case of failure at one of the facilities.

trans-unit.source: ZRS is currently available only for block blobs.
trans-unit.target: ZRS is currently available only for block blobs.

trans-unit.source: Note that once you have created your storage account and selected zone-redundant replication, you cannot convert it to use any other type of replication, or vice versa.
trans-unit.target: Note that once you have created your storage account and selected zone-redundant replication, you cannot convert it to use any other type of replication, or vice versa.

trans-unit.source: Geo-redundant storage (GRS) replicates your data to a secondary region that is hundreds of miles away from the primary region.
trans-unit.target: Geo-redundant storage (GRS) replicates your data to a secondary region that is hundreds of miles away from the primary region.

trans-unit.source: If your storage account has GRS enabled, then your data is durable even in the case of a complete regional outage or a disaster in which the primary region is not recoverable.
trans-unit.target: If your storage account has GRS enabled, then your data is durable even in the case of a complete regional outage or a disaster in which the primary region is not recoverable.

trans-unit.source: For a storage account with GRS enabled, an update is first committed to the primary region, where it is replicated three times.
trans-unit.target: For a storage account with GRS enabled, an update is first committed to the primary region, where it is replicated three times.

trans-unit.source: Then the update is replicated to the secondary region, where it is also replicated three times, across separate fault domains and upgrade domains.
trans-unit.target: Then the update is replicated to the secondary region, where it is also replicated three times, across separate fault domains and upgrade domains.

trans-unit.source: With GRS, requests to write data are replicated asynchronously to the secondary region.
trans-unit.target: With GRS, requests to write data are replicated asynchronously to the secondary region.

trans-unit.source: It is important to note that opting for GRS does not impact latency of requests made against the primary region.
trans-unit.target: It is important to note that opting for GRS does not impact latency of requests made against the primary region.

trans-unit.source: However, since asychronous replication involves a delay, in the event of a regional disaster it is possible that changes that have not yet been replicated to the secondary region may be lost if the data cannot be recovered from the primary region.
trans-unit.target: However, since asychronous replication involves a delay, in the event of a regional disaster it is possible that changes that have not yet been replicated to the secondary region may be lost if the data cannot be recovered from the primary region.

trans-unit.source: When you create a storage account, you select the primary region for the account.
trans-unit.target: When you create a storage account, you select the primary region for the account.

trans-unit.source: The secondary region is determined based on the primary region, and cannot be changed.
trans-unit.target: The secondary region is determined based on the primary region, and cannot be changed.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows the primary and secondary region pairings.
trans-unit.target: The following table shows the primary and secondary region pairings.

trans-unit.source: Read-access geo-redundant storage (RA-GRS) maximizes availability for your storage account, by providing read-only access to the data in the secondary location, in addition to the replication across two regions provided by GRS.
trans-unit.target: Read-access geo-redundant storage (RA-GRS) maximizes availability for your storage account, by providing read-only access to the data in the secondary location, in addition to the replication across two regions provided by GRS.

trans-unit.source: In the event that data becomes unavailable in the primary region, your application can read data from the secondary region.
trans-unit.target: In the event that data becomes unavailable in the primary region, your application can read data from the secondary region.

trans-unit.source: When you enable read-only access to your data in the secondary region, your data is available on a secondary endpoint, in addition to the primary endpoint for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: When you enable read-only access to your data in the secondary region, your data is available on a secondary endpoint, in addition to the primary endpoint for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: The secondary endpoint is similar to the primary endpoint, but appends the suffix –secondary to the account name.
trans-unit.target: The secondary endpoint is similar to the primary endpoint, but appends the suffix –secondary to the account name.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your primary endpoint for the Blob service is myaccount.blob.core.windows.net, then your secondary endpoint is myaccount-secondary.blob.core.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your primary endpoint for the Blob service is myaccount.blob.core.windows.net, then your secondary endpoint is myaccount-secondary.blob.core.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: The access keys for your storage account are the same for both the primary and secondary endpoints.
trans-unit.target: The access keys for your storage account are the same for both the primary and secondary endpoints.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure Storage redundancy options and read access geo redundant storage </linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Microsoft Azure Storage redundancy options and read access geo redundant storage </linkText><title></title></link>
